etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Charles Badham (1805–1857), naturalist. From synecdoche + -ism

definitions: Synecdochic style; the use of synecdoche.

A belief, or practice based on this belief, that a part of an object or person is equivalent to the whole, so that anything done to, or by means of, the part is held to take effect upon, or have the effect of, the whole.
